attributes.title: Political dissimilarity-centrality
attributes.description: Two-part field study with employees and supervisors investigating the interactive effect of employee-supervisor political dissimilarity and political identity centrality.

q1.value: Hana Johnson, Fong Highberger Keng, Yunhyung Chung, Elizabeth Umphress, Chak Fu LAM, Wen Wu

q2.value:
1. For path analysis: The positive effect of actual employee-supervisor political identity dissimilarity on perceived employee-supervisor political identity dissimilarity is strengthened when identity centrality and identity threat are higher.

1a. The indirect effect of actual employee-supervisor political identity dissimilarity on dependent variables (positive effect on: information elaboration, supervisor deviance, unethical pro-supervisor behaviors, conflict, ostracism; negative effect on: sense of power, supervisor identification, supervisor satisfaction, commitment to supervisor, supervisor trust, interactional justice, friendship, subordinate commitment, performance, supportive voice, challenging voice, helping behaviors, leadership emergence) is mediated by perceived employee-supervisor dissimilarity and moderated by identity centrality and identity threat, such that the indirect effects are strengthened when the moderators are higher.

2. For polynomial regression: Incongruence between actual employee political identity and supervisor political identity will be positively related to perceived employee-supervisor political dissimilarity.
2a. Political identity centrality moderates the relationship between actual political identity incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor political identity dissimilarity such that as centrality increases, the u-shaped relationship between actual political identity incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor political identity dissimilarity is strengthened. In other words, for this relationship, the curvature along the line of incongruence for actual employee-supervisor political identity will be more strongly negative as centrality increases. 
2b. Political identity threat moderates the relationship between actual political identity incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor political dissimilarity such that as political identity threat increases, the u-shaped relationship between actual SES incongruence and perceived employee-supervisor SES dissimilarity is strengthened. In other words, for this relationship, the curvature along the line of incongruence for actual employee-supervisor political identity will be more strongly negative as political identity threat increases.
2c. Perceived political identity dissimilarity will mediate the interactive relationship between actual political identity dissimilarity and identity centrality or identity threat on our dependent variables.

3. Exploratory: COVID-19 fear or anxiety is an antecedent to political identity threat in the hypotheses above.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional design with one survey fielded with employees at Time 2 and and another survey fielded with supervisors at Time 2 (4 weeks later than Time 1). There is no manipulation or randomization.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1. We are inviting online MBA students who are enrolled in a program at a large university in the Western U.S. to participate in a survey themselves and to recruit their supervisor to participate in a survey.
2. The instructor of the core required online MBA class will announce the participation in the study as an extra credit opportunity. Detailed information about the study will be posted on the class’ website. 
3. The MBA students emails one of the investigators with their email address and LinkedIn profile and the email address and LinkedIn profile of their supervisor. The investigator emails the survey link to the MBA student. 4 weeks later, the investigatory emails the survey link to the supervisor.
4. MBA students receive 1% of their overall class grade as extra credit for providing the email address/LinkedIn profile for their supervisors and themselves, and completing the employee survey. The MBA student and supervisor each earn an entry into a drawing to win a $200 Amazon gift card (10 winners) or $100 Amazon gift card (10 winners) upon completion of their respective surveys. The MBA student receives an additional 4 entries into the drawing if both the employee & supervisor complete their surveys. The MBA student will also receive a small pendant with the school's logo.
5. Due to IRB restrictions, only students living and working in the U.S. may participate.
6. The study timeline: survey launches March 30, 2020.

q11.value: There are approximately 500 online MBA students offered in the class for which extra credit is being offered. Each unit is an employee-supervisor dyad. So we will only be analyzing data for which the employee and his/her supervisor completes the survey.

q12.value: Our sample size is based on how many students are enrolled in the core online MBA class.

q13.value: The class runs from March 9, 2020 to April 26, 2020 so students may participate any time during that time period. The supervisor survey will be sent 4 weeks after the employee survey so it’s possible for the last supervisor survey to be emailed as late as May 22, 2020. We will allow supervisors up to 2 weeks to complete their survey so our estimate is that data collection will end mid-June 2020.

question.value:
Note: see appendix for all survey items & citations for each scale)
1. Predictors: “Actual self-supervisor dissimilarity” will be calculated in one of 2 ways depending on the type of analysis:
1a. Using path analysis: Calculated as the absolute difference between the employee and supervisor’s rating on the 1-item “political identity” measure. Then divide the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
1b. Using polynomial regression:  “Actual employee political identity” and "Actual supervisor political identity" will be the rating on the 1-item “political identity” measure for the employee and supervisor, respectively.

2. Moderators: 
2a. Identity centrality: mean of 10 items focused on “political identity”
2b. Identity threat: mean of 3 items focused on “political identity”
2c. COVID-19 fear: mean of 5 items
2d. COVID-19 anxiety: mean of 6 items

3. Mediators:
3a. Perceived employee-supervisor political dissimilarity: 4 items focused on  “political identity”

4. Dependent variables:
4a. Sense of power: 8 items
4b. Information elaboration: 3 items
4c. Supervisor identification: 6 items
4d. Supervisor satisfaction: 3 items
4e. Commitment to supervisor: 3 items
4f. Supervisor trust: 4 items
4g. Interactional justice: 4 items
4h. Supervisor deviance: 3 items
4i. Unethical pro-supervisor behaviors: 3 items 
4j. Relationship Conflict: 4 items
4k. Friendship: 5 items
4l. Subordinate commitment: 3 items
4m. Job performance: 5 items
4n. Supportive voice: 5 items
4o. Challenging voice: 7 items
4p. Helping behaviors: 3 items
4q. Ostracism: 4 items
4r. Leader emergence: 4 items

5. Control variables: Control in all analyses: Depending on our sample size and the complexity of analyses, we may have to first test to see if control variables below have an effect on our variables of interest and only control for the variables which do have an effect (due to adequate power concerns). If sample size is large enough, we can accommodate all control variables. 

5a. Gender dissimilarity: Coded gender as “same” (0) or “different” (1). Then divided the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
5b. Age dissimilarity: Absolute difference in age in years between employee & supervisor. Then divided the individual discrepancy score by respective standard deviation.
5c. Dyadic tenure
5d. # of minutes interact with supervisor each week
5e. Employee level within organization
5f. “State” employee/supervisor live in
5g. Belief that Republicans/Democrats are superior to Democrats/Republicans
5h. PANAS – 10 items

6. Also control in analyses with “supportive voice” or “challenging voice” as the DV:
6a. Individual psychological safety: 3 items
6b. Voice efficacy: 3 items
We will calculate either dissimilarity or the average of items as specified above for each variable in the “measured variables” section.

1. We will use path analysis in Mplus to test each path analysis hypothesis.
2. We will exclude all participants who do not pass the 2 attention checks embedded in the survey. We will test each moderated mediation hypothesis separately.
3. We will use R to test each moderated mediation hypothesis in our path analysis and generate 95% confidence intervals for the indirect effects. 
4. We will use polynomial regression in Mplus to test the polynomial regression hypotheses.
5. To test the mediation and moderated mediation hypotheses from the polynomial regression analyses, we will use the block variable approach as recommended by Edwards and Cable (2009).  
6. We will conduct simple slopes analyses for significant interactions in the path analysis.

q18.value: For polynomial regression, actual political identity and the moderators, identity centrality and identity threat, will be centered at the midpoint of the scale as recommended by Shanock, Baran, Gentry, Pattison, & Heggestad, 2010.

q19.value:
1. For path analysis, we will consider the p-value to be significant if < .05, and marginal if between .05-.10. We will use two tailed tests.
2. For path analysis, we will consider mediation to be supported if the 95%CI does not include 0.
3. For polynomial regression, a u-shaped relationship will be supported if the curvature along the incongruence line is significantly positive.
4. For polynomial regression, the strengthening of a u-shaped relationship will be supported if the coefficient for the curvature along the incongruence line gets larger and more positive as the moderator increases.
5. For polynomial regression, we will consider mediation to be significantly supported if the p-values for the relationship between the interaction and the mediator and the relationship between the mediator and the dependent variable are < .05 and marginally significant if between .05-.10. We will use two tailed tests.

q20.value:
1. Data will be excluded if both the employee and supervisor do not complete their respective surveys.
2. Data will be excluded for participants who have failed attention checks and for those who have no variance in responses (e.g., answers “3” for all items).
3. Data will be excluded if the employee and supervisor have not worked together for at least 6 months.
4. We will exclude outliers on dyadic tenure and interaction with supervisor if the participant is more than 3 standard deviations from the mean on either variable.

q21.value: Missing data will be specified as missing within SPSS and Mplus. Both use listwise deletion.

q22.value:
1. Perceived employee-supervisor deep level dissimilarity (5 items) as a mediator instead of Perceived employee-supervisor political dissimilarity
2. Control for Perceived employee-team dissimilarity: 1 item for “political identity”
3. Control for COVID-19 impact: change in % of job conducted remotely, change in # of minutes interact with supervisor each week in-person, satisfaction with telecommuting, disruption of work as a result of COVID-19, whether someone close to employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19

attributes.title: Agreeableness, self-regulation, reactions to hurtful incidents
attributes.description: This study aims to investigate the roles of agreeableness, communal motivation, trust, and self-regulation in people’s constructive and destructive responses to hurt feelings in romantic relationships. Specifically, we focus on people’s expressions of hurt feelings, forgiveness toward their partner, and perceived partner intentionality in hurting them. More positive, direct expressions, fewer negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, and lower perceived partner intentionality are considered as more constructive and less destructive responses to hurt feelings.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
Agreeableness:
--between-participant
--measured using: 1. Big Five Inventory—agreeableness subscale (John et al., 1991), 2. Big Five Aspect Scale—Agreeableness subscale (John et al., 2008), and 3.Ten Item Personality Inventory (Gosling et al., 2003)

Cognitive load:
--between-participant
--We will randomly assign participants to either a high cognitive load or low cognitive load condition. In the high load condition, participants will be asked to memorize and rehearse a 9-digit number while completing the dependent variables. In the low load condition, participants will be asked to memorize and rehearse a 3-digit number while completing the dependent variables.

We expect these variables to be orthogonal.

question2b.value:
DEPENDENT VARIABLES:
1. Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform:
--Participants will complete a measure of the extent to which they will do certain actions next time when they encounter an emotionally hurtful incident. The items of the measure are taken from past studies that we have conducted on expressions of hurt feelings. Items capture positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negative, indirect expressions of hurt feelings, affectionate acts, and behaviors that reflect covert optimism. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on a combination of the results of principal component analysis on the data and a priori theoretical ground. 
2. Attribution and Forgiveness:
--Participants will indicate the next time they encounter a hurtful incident, the extent to which they will think their partner hurts them intentionally and the extent to which they will forgive their partner

MEDIATING VARIABLES 
1. General Trust: Items are taken from trust measures used in McCarthy et al., (2017) and Cortes and Wood (2019)
2. General Communal motivation: Communal Orientation Scale (Clark et al., 1987)
3. General Self-Regulation Ability: Short Version of Self-Control Scale (Tangney et al., 2004)

EXPLORATORY VARIABLES
1. Love for partner (Fletcher et al., 2000)
2. State attitudes regarding relationships: Participants will indicate how they view their relationship and their partner at the moment. Items adapted from Murray et al., (2000; 2002)
3. Emotions one anticipates to experience in future hurtful incident: Participants will indicate the extent to which they anticipate feeling upset, irritated, angry, hurt, and sad in a future hurtful incident.
4. Relationship Satisfaction (Rusbult et al., 1998)
5. Expressions of hurt feelings that participants want to perform: Sometime people are tempted to do things that they will not do. Participants will complete a measure of what they will want to do following a future hurtful incident. 
6. Self-Esteem (Rosenberg, 1965)

question10b.value:
Participants first complete the following measures: (a) Big-Five Inventory--Agreeableness Subscale, (b) Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, (c) Big Five Aspect Scale-Agreeableness Subscale, (d) Ten Item Personality Inventory, (d) general trust, (e) general communal motivation, (f) general self-regulation, and (g) love for partner. 
Then, they will recall and describe a past hurtful incident. Next, they will be randomly assigned to either the high cognitive load (High) or low cognitive load (Low) condition. Participants in High will be asked to memorize a 9-digit number throughout the study and participants in Low will be asked to memorize a 3-digit number. They will be asked NOT to use external aids to help memorize the number because it is really important for our study and doing so would invalidate the data and severely compromise our research. They will also be told that if they can correctly recall the number later in the study, they will receive a bonus payment. Following these instructions, they will be presented with a string of number. 
After that, participants will complete measures of (a) expressions of hurt feelings that they intend to perform next time they are hurt, (b) attribution and forgiveness, (c) state attitudes toward their current relationships, (d) emotion to be expected next time they are hurt, (e) expressions of hurt feelings that they may way to perform.
Next, they will be asked to recall the number. Then, they will report their relationship satisfaction, recall a time that they were happy in their relationship as a mood boost, provide demographic information (i.e., gender, age, ethnicity, relationship length, relationship status). 
Lastly, they will report whether they have used any external aids to memorize the number, how hard they have tried to memorize the number, and their level of study engagement (i.e., how distracted were they, how engaged were they, and how honest/accurate were their answers). They will also be given the opportunity to write to us any feedback they have regarding this study.

question4b.value: Participants are required to be in a current romantic relationship and have experienced a past emotionally hurtful incident in their current relationship.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk).

question6b.value:
Based on power analysis assuming  medium effect size (i.e., all beta’s = 0.30), to ensure 80% power with an alpha level of .05, we will need 250 participants. 
Due to limited funds, 250 is also the number of participants that we can afford.

question7b.value: We will stop data collection once the N is reached on MTurk.

question8b.value:
i.	Participants who do not complete the majority of the study (e.g., missing multiple key variables) will be excluded.
ii.	Participants who provide non-sensical response (e.g., one-word response, repeated response, short phrases / sentences that do not make sense or answer the question) to the open-ended questions about describing a hurtful incident and a happy memory will be excluded.
iii.	Participants who report not having experienced anything hurtful in their relationship will be excluded

question1a.value:
1. Agreeableness is associated positively with positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negatively with negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, positively with forgiveness, negatively with perceived partner intentionality.
2. Participants in the high cognitive load condition will report less positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, more negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower forgiveness, and higher perceived partner intentionality.
3. Through higher level of general trust, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
4. Through higher level of general communal motivation, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
5. Through higher level of general self-regulation ability, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
We will examine how condition moderates the above three hypothesized mediational associations (Hypotheses 3-5). However, because we are uncertain how condition moderates the effects of agreeableness, we do not have specific hypotheses regarding whether and how the mediational associations would differ across the two conditions.

question2a.value:
The effects of agreeableness are moderated by condition. We make two competing hypotheses regarding how condition would moderate the effects of agreeableness. 
1. People require self-regulatory ability to regulate their destructive responses to hurt feelings, and people under high cognitive load should have lower self-regulation ability (e.g., Rusbult et al., 1991). As such, one prediction is that the effects of agreeableness would be weaker in the high cognitive load condition than in the low cognitive load condition. 
2. However, other research has shown that when under high cognitive load, the effects of agreeableness on destructive and constructive responses to relationship conflicts are actually stronger than the effects of agreeableness under low cognitive load (Perunovic & Holmes, 2008). This finding suggests that agreeable people’s high constructive and low destructive tendencies are so ingrained that these tendencies become automatic, appearing even under high cognitive load. As such, a second, competing prediction is that the effects of agreeableness would be stronger in the high cognitive load condition than in the low cognitive load condition.

question3a.value: We expect that the effect of cognitive load will be reflected in differences in our DVs according to our hypotheses illustrated above. As such, we will not include a manipulation check.

question1c.value:
For all variables, univariate outliers are defined as values than are more than 3 SDs above or below the mean. Variables with outliers will be winsorized (i.e., replace any value outside of 3 SDs above or below the mean with the value at 3 SDs from the mean).  

RELEVANT VARIABLES TO BE CALCULATED:
i.	Agreeableness. Three agreeableness scores will be computed from each of the three agreeableness measures. We will focus generally on the Big Five Inventory-Agreeableness subscale as our main predictor. We will also examine the BFAS and TIPI-Agreeableness subscale.
ii.	General trust, general communal motivation, general self-regulation, love for partner, and relationship satisfaction. Each variable will be created by taking an average of the items of their corresponding scale. Items that are supposed to be reverse-scored will be reverse-scored.
iii.	Cognitive load/Condition Variable. Cognitive load variable will be effects coded (-1 = low load, 1 = high load) and dummy coded. 
iv.	Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform. Based on the principal component analysis and scree plot of this scale in our past study, we expect 5 factors to emerge—a) positive, direct expressions, b) negative, direct expressions, c) covert optimistic behaviors, d) negative, indirect expressions, and e) affectionate behaviors. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on the results of the principal component analysis and the scree plot. Items will need to have a factor loading of at least .32 in order to be considered as part of a factor. Items with factor loadings that exceed .32 for more than one will be dropped, unless the difference in the factor loadings exceed .30, in which case the item will be classified as belonging to the factor to which it loads more strongly.
v.	Attribution. The item “the hurtful incident is an accident” will be reverse-scored. An average of attribution will be computed with this reverse-scored item, and the other 5 items (i.e., my partner is insensitive or inconsiderate; my partner is trying to hurt me; my partner’s behavior is intentional; my partner is deserving of blame; my partner’s behavior is motivated by concerns that are selfish).
vi.	Forgiveness. An average will be created from two items (i.e., forgive my partner for hurting me; completely forgive my partner).

question2c.value:
i.	Multiple regression will be conducted to test our hypotheses. We will regress each outcome variable (e.g., negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings) on agreeableness (mean-centered), condition (high load vs. low load; effects coded), and their interaction term. If there is a significant interaction, we will probe the effect of agreeableness in both high- and low-load conditions using dummy codes, and the effect of condition at +1 SD and -1 SD of agreeableness. (If there is no significant condition effect, we will collapse across conditions and regress the outcome variables only on agreeableness.)
ii.	Mediation analyses will be run to test the hypotheses regarding indirect pathways as listed under hypotheses. Mediation analyses will be conducted using the “lavaan” package in R (Rosseel, 2012). Simple mediation analyses will be run for each outcome variable and each hypothesized mediator separately. For example, one model will examine agreeableness as the predictor, general communal motivation as the mediator, and negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings as the outcome variable. Another model will involve the same predictor and mediator, but with a different outcome variable, such as forgiveness. We will also run moderated mediation analyses to examine whether and how condition affects the pattern of the indirect pathways.

question3c.value:
Agreeableness will be a predictor. Condition will be a predictor. The interaction/product term between agreeableness and condition will also be a predictor. 
General trust, general communal motivation, general self-regulation will be mediators.
Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform, attribution, and forgiveness will be outcome variables.

question1c.value:
VARIABLES FOR EXLPORATORY ANALYSES
i.   Expressions of hurt feelings that participants want to perform. Based on the principal component analysis and scree plot of this scale in our past study, we expect 5 factors to emerge—a) positive, direct expressions, b) negative, direct expressions, c) covert optimistic behaviors, d) negative, indirect expressions, and e) affectionate behaviors. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on the results of the principal component analysis and the scree plot. Items will need to have a factor loading of at least .32 in order to be considered as part of a factor. Items with factor loadings that exceed .32 for more than one will be dropped, unless the difference in the factor loadings exceed .30, in which case the item will be classified as belonging to the factor to which it loads more strongly.
ii.  Emotions to be expected following the next hurtful incident. Participants' ratings on each of the five emotions to be expected (i.e., hurt, angry, sad, irritable, upset) will be used as score for each of the five emotions.

registration_responses.datacompletion: Yes, data collection is underway or complete
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1. Agreeableness is associated positively with positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negatively with negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, positively with forgiveness, negatively with perceived partner intentionality.
2. Participants in the high cognitive load condition will report less positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, more negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower forgiveness, and higher perceived partner intentionality.
3. Through higher level of general trust, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
4. Through higher level of general communal motivation, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
5. Through higher level of general self-regulation ability, there will be indirect pathways from agreeableness to higher direct expressions of hurt feelings, lower negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, higher forgiveness, lower perceived partner intentionality.
We will examine how condition moderates the above three hypothesized mediational associations (Hypotheses 3-5). However, because we are uncertain how condition moderates the effects of agreeableness, we do not have specific hypotheses regarding whether and how the mediational associations would differ across the two conditions.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
The effects of agreeableness are moderated by condition. We make two competing hypotheses regarding how condition would moderate the effects of agreeableness. 
1. People require self-regulatory ability to regulate their destructive responses to hurt feelings, and people under high cognitive load should have lower self-regulation ability (e.g., Rusbult et al., 1991). As such, one prediction is that the effects of agreeableness would be weaker in the high cognitive load condition than in the low cognitive load condition. 
2. However, other research has shown that when under high cognitive load, the effects of agreeableness on destructive and constructive responses to relationship conflicts are actually stronger than the effects of agreeableness under low cognitive load (Perunovic & Holmes, 2008). This finding suggests that agreeable people’s high constructive and low destructive tendencies are so ingrained that these tendencies become automatic, appearing even under high cognitive load. As such, a second, competing prediction is that the effects of agreeableness would be stronger in the high cognitive load condition than in the low cognitive load condition.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We expect that the effect of cognitive load will be reflected in differences in our DVs according to our hypotheses illustrated above. As such, we will not include a manipulation check.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Agreeableness:
--between-participant
--measured using: 1. Big Five Inventory—agreeableness subscale (John et al., 1991), 2. Big Five Aspect Scale—Agreeableness subscale (John et al., 2008), and 3.Ten Item Personality Inventory (Gosling et al., 2003)

Cognitive load:
--between-participant
--We will randomly assign participants to either a high cognitive load or low cognitive load condition. In the high load condition, participants will be asked to memorize and rehearse a 9-digit number while completing the dependent variables. In the low load condition, participants will be asked to memorize and rehearse a 3-digit number while completing the dependent variables.

We expect these variables to be orthogonal.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
DEPENDENT VARIABLES:
1. Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform:
--Participants will complete a measure of the extent to which they will do certain actions next time when they encounter an emotionally hurtful incident. The items of the measure are taken from past studies that we have conducted on expressions of hurt feelings. Items capture positive, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings, negative, indirect expressions of hurt feelings, affectionate acts, and behaviors that reflect covert optimism. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on a combination of the results of principal component analysis on the data and a priori theoretical ground. 
2. Attribution and Forgiveness:
--Participants will indicate the next time they encounter a hurtful incident, the extent to which they will think their partner hurts them intentionally and the extent to which they will forgive their partner

MEDIATING VARIABLES 
1. General Trust: Items are taken from trust measures used in McCarthy et al., (2017) and Cortes and Wood (2019)
2. General Communal motivation: Communal Orientation Scale (Clark et al., 1987)
3. General Self-Regulation Ability: Short Version of Self-Control Scale (Tangney et al., 2004)

EXPLORATORY VARIABLES
1. Love for partner (Fletcher et al., 2000)
2. State attitudes regarding relationships: Participants will indicate how they view their relationship and their partner at the moment. Items adapted from Murray et al., (2000; 2002)
3. Emotions one anticipates to experience in future hurtful incident: Participants will indicate the extent to which they anticipate feeling upset, irritated, angry, hurt, and sad in a future hurtful incident.
4. Relationship Satisfaction (Rusbult et al., 1998)
5. Expressions of hurt feelings that participants want to perform: Sometime people are tempted to do things that they will not do. Participants will complete a measure of what they will want to do following a future hurtful incident. 
6. Self-Esteem (Rosenberg, 1965)
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants first complete the following measures: (a) Big-Five Inventory--Agreeableness Subscale, (b) Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, (c) Big Five Aspect Scale-Agreeableness Subscale, (d) Ten Item Personality Inventory, (d) general trust, (e) general communal motivation, (f) general self-regulation, and (g) love for partner. 
Then, they will recall and describe a past hurtful incident. Next, they will be randomly assigned to either the high cognitive load (High) or low cognitive load (Low) condition. Participants in High will be asked to memorize a 9-digit number throughout the study and participants in Low will be asked to memorize a 3-digit number. They will be asked NOT to use external aids to help memorize the number because it is really important for our study and doing so would invalidate the data and severely compromise our research. They will also be told that if they can correctly recall the number later in the study, they will receive a bonus payment. Following these instructions, they will be presented with a string of number. 
After that, participants will complete measures of (a) expressions of hurt feelings that they intend to perform next time they are hurt, (b) attribution and forgiveness, (c) state attitudes toward their current relationships, (d) emotion to be expected next time they are hurt, (e) expressions of hurt feelings that they may way to perform.
Next, they will be asked to recall the number. Then, they will report their relationship satisfaction, recall a time that they were happy in their relationship as a mood boost, provide demographic information (i.e., gender, age, ethnicity, relationship length, relationship status). 
Lastly, they will report whether they have used any external aids to memorize the number, how hard they have tried to memorize the number, and their level of study engagement (i.e., how distracted were they, how engaged were they, and how honest/accurate were their answers). They will also be given the opportunity to write to us any feedback they have regarding this study.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
For all variables, univariate outliers are defined as values than are more than 3 SDs above or below the mean. Variables with outliers will be winsorized (i.e., replace any value outside of 3 SDs above or below the mean with the value at 3 SDs from the mean).  

RELEVANT VARIABLES TO BE CALCULATED:
i.	Agreeableness. Three agreeableness scores will be computed from each of the three agreeableness measures. We will focus generally on the Big Five Inventory-Agreeableness subscale as our main predictor. We will also examine the BFAS and TIPI-Agreeableness subscale.
ii.	General trust, general communal motivation, general self-regulation, love for partner, and relationship satisfaction. Each variable will be created by taking an average of the items of their corresponding scale. Items that are supposed to be reverse-scored will be reverse-scored.
iii.	Cognitive load/Condition Variable. Cognitive load variable will be effects coded (-1 = low load, 1 = high load) and dummy coded. 
iv.	Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform. Based on the principal component analysis and scree plot of this scale in our past study, we expect 5 factors to emerge—a) positive, direct expressions, b) negative, direct expressions, c) covert optimistic behaviors, d) negative, indirect expressions, and e) affectionate behaviors. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on the results of the principal component analysis and the scree plot. Items will need to have a factor loading of at least .32 in order to be considered as part of a factor. Items with factor loadings that exceed .32 for more than one will be dropped, unless the difference in the factor loadings exceed .30, in which case the item will be classified as belonging to the factor to which it loads more strongly.
v.	Attribution. The item “the hurtful incident is an accident” will be reverse-scored. An average of attribution will be computed with this reverse-scored item, and the other 5 items (i.e., my partner is insensitive or inconsiderate; my partner is trying to hurt me; my partner’s behavior is intentional; my partner is deserving of blame; my partner’s behavior is motivated by concerns that are selfish).
vi.	Forgiveness. An average will be created from two items (i.e., forgive my partner for hurting me; completely forgive my partner).

i.	Multiple regression will be conducted to test our hypotheses. We will regress each outcome variable (e.g., negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings) on agreeableness (mean-centered), condition (high load vs. low load; effects coded), and their interaction term. If there is a significant interaction, we will probe the effect of agreeableness in both high- and low-load conditions using dummy codes, and the effect of condition at +1 SD and -1 SD of agreeableness. (If there is no significant condition effect, we will collapse across conditions and regress the outcome variables only on agreeableness.)
ii.	Mediation analyses will be run to test the hypotheses regarding indirect pathways as listed under hypotheses. Mediation analyses will be conducted using the “lavaan” package in R (Rosseel, 2012). Simple mediation analyses will be run for each outcome variable and each hypothesized mediator separately. For example, one model will examine agreeableness as the predictor, general communal motivation as the mediator, and negative, direct expressions of hurt feelings as the outcome variable. Another model will involve the same predictor and mediator, but with a different outcome variable, such as forgiveness. We will also run moderated mediation analyses to examine whether and how condition affects the pattern of the indirect pathways.

Agreeableness will be a predictor. Condition will be a predictor. The interaction/product term between agreeableness and condition will also be a predictor. 
General trust, general communal motivation, general self-regulation will be mediators.
Expressions of hurt feelings that participants intend to perform, attribution, and forgiveness will be outcome variables.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants are required to be in a current romantic relationship and have experienced a past emotionally hurtful incident in their current relationship.
Participants will be recruited on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk).

Based on power analysis assuming  medium effect size (i.e., all beta’s = 0.30), to ensure 80% power with an alpha level of .05, we will need 250 participants. 
Due to limited funds, 250 is also the number of participants that we can afford.
We will stop data collection once the N is reached on MTurk.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
VARIABLES FOR EXLPORATORY ANALYSES
i.   Expressions of hurt feelings that participants want to perform. Based on the principal component analysis and scree plot of this scale in our past study, we expect 5 factors to emerge—a) positive, direct expressions, b) negative, direct expressions, c) covert optimistic behaviors, d) negative, indirect expressions, and e) affectionate behaviors. Specific items that fall under each category will depend on the results of the principal component analysis and the scree plot. Items will need to have a factor loading of at least .32 in order to be considered as part of a factor. Items with factor loadings that exceed .32 for more than one will be dropped, unless the difference in the factor loadings exceed .30, in which case the item will be classified as belonging to the factor to which it loads more strongly.
ii.  Emotions to be expected following the next hurtful incident. Participants' ratings on each of the five emotions to be expected (i.e., hurt, angry, sad, irritable, upset) will be used as score for each of the five emotions.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
i.	Participants who do not complete the majority of the study (e.g., missing multiple key variables) will be excluded.
ii.	Participants who provide non-sensical response (e.g., one-word response, repeated response, short phrases / sentences that do not make sense or answer the question) to the open-ended questions about describing a hurtful incident and a happy memory will be excluded.
iii.	Participants who report not having experienced anything hurtful in their relationship will be excluded

attributes.title: Opportunities for Surveilling Policies and Environments in Support of Healthy Eating, Breastfeeding, and Physical Activity in Rural United States Communities: A Scoping Review

comments.value: Gray literature searching has begun upon registration of this protocol. The academic search has been completed; however, review of full-text has not yet started.

attributes.title: The effects of person-first language on stigmatization of mental illness
attributes.description: The American Psychological Association (APA) advocates the use of person-first language to refer to individuals with mental illnesses in scholarly writing. The rationale behind this is based on the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, which posits that language shapes cognition, and therefore, the use of person-first language can reduce bias. The aim of this study is to determine whether person-first language effectively reduces bias, and, if so, are there differences between disorders. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions based on language use. The conditions will be (1) person-first language, (2)  identity-first language, and (3) noun-based language. For each, they will read and rate three job applications with three different disorders: (1) schizophrenia, (2) major depressive disorder (MDD), and (3) epilepsy.  We will also examine whether perceived social status, perceived dangerousness, and level of contact with mental illness would moderate this relationship.

q2.value:
We hypothesized that person-first language would result in lower stigmatization, whereas 
noun-based language would result in greater stigmatization.We also predicted that the effects of stigma would differ based on disorder, with highly stigmatized disorders (e.g., schizophrenia) having greater effect sizes than less stigmatized disorders (e.g., depression). Stigmatization of mental illness is influenced by social status (Link & Phelan, 2001), intimacy with mental illnesses (Holmes et al., 1999), and the overall belief that persons with mental illness are dangerous (Link et al., 1987; Angermeyer et al., 2003). Because of this, we predicted that subjective social status, level of contact, and perceived dangerousness would moderate the relationship between language and stigmatization.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We used an experimental task in which participants were randomly assigned to one of three language conditions: (1) person-first, (2) identity-first, and (3) noun-based. All participants read three (fictional) job applications in which each applicant disclosed having one of three disabilities: (1) schizophrenia, (2) major depressive disorder (MDD), and (3) epilepsy. Participants were asked to evaluate employability of the applicants using power, competence, personality, and professionalism as the outcome measures. Moderator variables include participant’s subjective social status, perceived dangerousness of individuals with mental illnesses, and level of intimacy with mental illnesses.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three language conditions (person-first language, identity-first language, and noun-based language), in which they will read three fictional job applications. In each application, the fictional applicant discloses having one of three disorders (schizophrenia, major depressive disorder, or epilepsy). Order of job applications will be randomized within-subject. Both levels of randomization will be conducted automatically by Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the University of California, Berkeley Department of Psychology’s Research Participation Program (RPP) website and through Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk). A brief description of the study will be posted on the RPP website and the Amazon MTurk website.

Participants recruited through RPP will not be excluded for the study for any specific reason other than age (those who are < 18 are not eligible to complete adult informed consent). Any student age 18 or older who participates in the Research Participation Program (RPP) will be welcome to participate in the study. RPP does not allow students under 18 to participate. Subjects must be fluent in English to participate in the study.

Participants recruited through MTurk will not be excluded for the study for any specific reason other than age and the country they live in. All MTurk subjects age 18 or older than live within the US will be welcome to participate. MTurk subjects must also be fluent in English to participate in the study.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 303 participants. We will attempt to collect up to 400 participants, assuming that some participants will not complete the entire study or will fail catch-trials.

q12.value: A priori power analyses were conducted using G*Power to estimate required sample size for the main effect of language condition, and the interactive effect of language condition x disorder.  Using alpha = .05 and estimating an effect size of  d = .25, a sample size of 303 would provide 95% power for the main effect and the interaction term.

question.value:
We will manipulate the type of language-modifier the participant read in the job applications. The three language conditions are (1) person-first language, (2) identity-first language, and (3) noun-based language.

Person-first language frames the person first rather than the disability (e.g., “a person with schizophrenia”). Identity-first language frames the disability first, then the person. (e.g., “a schizophrenic person”) Noun-based language refers to the person as their disorder or disability (e.g., “a schizophrenic”).

The outcome measure will be perceived employability of the job applicant. The 22-item Employee Characteristics Scale (ECS) measures the employability of a job applicant (Christman & Slaten, 1991). The original 22-item scale measures personality, power, competence, and professionalism of applicants (example items include: Intelligent, Powerful, Competent, Cooperative, and Strong). Because stigma influences perceived competence (Sadler & Vaughn, 2015), four more items were added from the stereotype content model (Fiske et al., 2002) to measure competence. Ratings will be completed on a scale of 1 “Not at all” to 7 “Extremely.” After reading each application, participants will be asked to rate how much each characteristic was true of the applicant.

Perceived social status was measured using The MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler et al., 2000, Ostrove et al., 2000). Participants were shown a picture of a ladder with rungs labeled from 1 through 10. Participants were instructed that the bottom of the ladder represented people who were the worst off (e.g., had the least education, least money, and least respected jobs), while the top of the ladder represented people who were the best off (e.g., had the most education, most money, and most respected jobs). The single rating served as the participants' score for their subjective social status.

 The Dangerousness Scale (Penn et al., 1994) was used to measure perceived dangerousness, or participants’ beliefs about whether individuals with mental illness are dangerous (Sample items: “If I know a person has a mental illness, I will be less likely to trust him”; “If a formal mental patient applied for a teaching position at a grade school, I would recommend hiring him/her.” [reversed]). Ratings were completed on a scale of  1 “Strongly agree” to 7 “Strongly disagree.” Rather than pertaining directly to the character in the vignette, the items on the scale pertain to generalized beliefs about individuals with mental illness.

We used the Level of Contact Report (Holmes et al., 1999) to measure the level of intimate contact with mental illness. The scale consists of 12 items ranging from low intimacy (i.e.,  “I have watched a movie or a television show in which a character depicted a person with mental illness”) to high intimacy (“I live with a person with a mental illness”). Each item was given a ranking of intimacy, from 1 to 12. Participants were instructed to select all items that applied to them. The highest ranked item served as the participant’s score for level of contact.

Before conducting analyses of hypotheses, all variables will be graphed and assessed for normality. Chi-square tests will be used for dichotomous variables and Pearson correlations will be used for continuous variables (unless the data are observed to be non-normal, in which case non-parametric tests will be used). We will include control variables as indicated. To test our main hypotheses, we will use 3 x 3 ANCOVAs to test for the main effects of language, disorder, and the interaction term of language and disorders, on the dependent variables of employability characteristics. We will include moderators (e.g. level of contact, perceived dangerousness, and perceived social status) as indicated.

q19.value: We will use the standard p <.05 criteria for determining if the ANCOVA test suggests significant differences in results from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: 7 catch-item trials were included for each condition to ensure that participants were paying attention. Participants will be excluded if they fail at least 50% of catch-item trials.

registration_responses.q2:
We hypothesized that person-first language would result in lower stigmatization, whereas 
noun-based language would result in greater stigmatization.We also predicted that the effects of stigma would differ based on disorder, with highly stigmatized disorders (e.g., schizophrenia) having greater effect sizes than less stigmatized disorders (e.g., depression). Stigmatization of mental illness is influenced by social status (Link & Phelan, 2001), intimacy with mental illnesses (Holmes et al., 1999), and the overall belief that persons with mental illness are dangerous (Link et al., 1987; Angermeyer et al., 2003). Because of this, we predicted that subjective social status, level of contact, and perceived dangerousness would moderate the relationship between language and stigmatization.

attributes.title: Automation Risk and Support for a Universal Basic Income

q1.value: Automation Risk and Support for a Universal Basic Income

q2.value: Rorisang Lekalake | Zachary Daniel Markovich | Gabriel Nahmias | Stuart Russell

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This experiment is aimed at confirming the effect of an experimental manipulation on perceptions of the economic threat that workers face from automation and support for a UBI. In the first round, we discovered that our intervention was able to successful increase concerns about automation, but that there was significant heterogeneity in the effect of support for a UBI. In particular, a positive effect was identified for participants over 38 without a college degree, who we theorize would face the most difficulty retraining or finding a new job. Furthermore, a negative effect was identified for participants of retirement age, who we theorize are less concerned about the effects of automation on their income and more concerned about the effects of redistributive policies on their taxes. This experiment aims at replicating these findings.

q16.value: 1) The intervention will increase the perceived threat of automation induced job losses. 2) This effect will be associated with increases in support for redistributive government programs. In particular, a Universal Basic Income, but also policies like job retraining and other ways of strengthening the safety net. 3) There will be meaningful heterogeneity in these effects. 3a) Workers that would face difficulty retraining (specifically, those over 38 without a college degree) will display the largest effects. 3b) Effects will be null or possibly even negative for workers that would not face difficulty retraining. 3c) Those of retirement age will display a negative effect.

q17.value: Our intervention is a sham survey that a respondent takes about their current, previous, or aspirant jobs. Respondents are randomized to be given either an optimistic (indicating their job is unlikely to be automated) or pessimistic (indicating a high probability of automation) result from this survey. Automation anxiety will be assessed with a battery of questions measuring perceptions of sociotropic and egotropic economic risk. Support for policy positions will be measured by a series of questions about support various policy attitudes. We will also include survey questions about a respondents demographics.

registration_responses.q1: Automation Risk and Support for a Universal Basic Income
registration_responses.q2: Rorisang Lekalake | Zachary Daniel Markovich | Gabriel Nahmias | Stuart Russell
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: This experiment is aimed at confirming the effect of an experimental manipulation on perceptions of the economic threat that workers face from automation and support for a UBI. In the first round, we discovered that our intervention was able to successful increase concerns about automation, but that there was significant heterogeneity in the effect of support for a UBI. In particular, a positive effect was identified for participants over 38 without a college degree, who we theorize would face the most difficulty retraining or finding a new job. Furthermore, a negative effect was identified for participants of retirement age, who we theorize are less concerned about the effects of automation on their income and more concerned about the effects of redistributive policies on their taxes. This experiment aims at replicating these findings.
registration_responses.q16: 1) The intervention will increase the perceived threat of automation induced job losses. 2) This effect will be associated with increases in support for redistributive government programs. In particular, a Universal Basic Income, but also policies like job retraining and other ways of strengthening the safety net. 3) There will be meaningful heterogeneity in these effects. 3a) Workers that would face difficulty retraining (specifically, those over 38 without a college degree) will display the largest effects. 3b) Effects will be null or possibly even negative for workers that would not face difficulty retraining. 3c) Those of retirement age will display a negative effect.
registration_responses.q17: Our intervention is a sham survey that a respondent takes about their current, previous, or aspirant jobs. Respondents are randomized to be given either an optimistic (indicating their job is unlikely to be automated) or pessimistic (indicating a high probability of automation) result from this survey. Automation anxiety will be assessed with a battery of questions measuring perceptions of sociotropic and egotropic economic risk. Support for policy positions will be measured by a series of questions about support various policy attitudes. We will also include survey questions about a respondents demographics.

attributes.title: Crime and Covid-19: Effect of changes activities in Mexico City
attributes.description: This study seeks to examine the effect of the covid-19-related changes in routine activities on crime patterns in an urban area. Using data from Mexico City, I will first identify a suitable proxy measure to estimate the amount of activity outside homes (such as public transit passenger numbers, mobility apps trip queries, or amount of air pollution) before and after the social distancing restrictions imposed due to the Covid-19 epidemic. Then, I will examine if spatio-temporal crime patterns are associated with those of the proxy measures of routine activities.

q2.value:
1. The incidence of crime in public places will decrease as the amount of air pollution decreases following a reduction of vehicular traffic due to the covid-19 lockdown.
2. The incidence of crime in public places will decrease as the amount of trip queries in urban mobility application decreases following a reduction of city trips due to the covid-19 lockdown.
3. The incidence of crime in public places will decrease as the amount of passengers in public transport decreases following a reduction of commuting due to the covid-19 lockdown.
4. The incidence of crime in private residences will increase as the amount of air pollution decreases following a reduction of vehicular traffic due to the covid-19 lockdown.
5. The incidence of crime in private residences will increase as the amount of trip queries in urban mobility application decreases following a reduction of city trips due to the covid-19 lockdown.
6. The incidence of crime in private residences will increase as the amount of passengers in public transport decreases following a reduction of commuting due to the covid-19 lockdown.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Longitudinal study: city-wide time series analysis.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: Though the data that will be used is secondary, it has not been generated yet as it refers to measurements of social phenomena occurring at the time of writing and the future.

question.value: Data will be collected from third-party open data repositories. Crime incidence, air pollution and public transport passenger data is reported by the Mexico City government on a regular basis. Data on trip queries in urban mobility apps will be collected from the app developer company.

q11.value:
I aim to obtain at least a year of pre-lockdown data, and at least three months  of post-lockdown data. Observations will be aggregated to daily or weekly counts, depending on their quality.

As the analyses will be conducted city-wide, one spatial unit will be used for the main analysis. However, additional sub-city units (neighbourhoods, street segments) may be used in exploratory analyses.

q12.value:
At the moment it is unknown how long the movement restrictions due to covid-19 lockdown restrictions will last. Thus, the estimate for the sample size was selected using the following rationale:

- Pre-lockdown period:
    - A year is the minimum period required to be able to capture seasonal trends for the post-lockdown counterfactual trend.
- Post-lockdown period:
    - A month could conceivably be enough to show an effect (using daily data), but if data are aggregated by week, it will not be sensitive enough to detect differences in crime trends. Longer would be better, but three months seems like a good compromise for a first assessment. In follow up studies, the period could extended to capture whether crime patterns resume their original trajectory as (if) Mexico City resumes its usual activity patterns.

question.value:
- Dependent variable (per day and/or week):
    - Counts of crimes of the following categories (the specific crime types used are to be determined depending on data availability).
- Independent variable (per day and/or week):
    - Air pollution:
        - 24h average of PM10 and PM2.5 suspended atmospheric particles.
        - 24h average of atmospheric sulphur dioxide levels.
    - Urban mobility queries:
        - Citymapper Mobility Index
    - Public transport passengers:
        - Daily number of passengers using bus rapid transit (Metrobus) system.
        - Daily number of passengers using metro system.

Interrupted time series regression is an appropriate approach to model the effects of covid-19 related restrictions on crime. This involves estimating whether the trend of crime incidents per unit time changes after a discrete time period (when a city-wide lockdown was imposed, for example). 

However, so far the restrictions on city movements have not been consistently implemented, and there have been reports of many people flouting authorities' recommendations to stay at home. Thus, it is possible that a better alternative for causal inference may be to model crime incidence against a suitable proxy for routine activities. In this study, I propose using air pollution, trip queries in mobility apps, and passenger numbers in public transport in bivariate models with crime incidence as the dependent variable.

Given the longitudinal nature of the data, observations of the dependent variable are likely to be serially correlated, exhibit seasonality and an inherent trend. Thus, I will use ARIMA methods to control such temporal patterns.

To avoid contaminating the ARIMA components with the effect of the covid-19 restrictions, I will estimate the components using data for before the epidemic reached Mexico (up until Februrary 2020, though this is subject to results of the exploratory analysis).

q19.value: I will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the coefficients of the independent variables are significantly different from zero as predicted in the null hypotheses.

q22.value: Spatio-temporal data analysis will be used to explore how patterns of the dependent and independent variables changed during the observation period, with particular attention to changes in the extent and distribution during the pre- and post-lockdown periods.

2. The incidence of crime in public places will decrease as the amount of trip queries in urban mobility application decreases following a reduction of city trips due to the covid-19 lockdown.
3. The incidence of crime in public places will decrease as the amount of passengers in public transport decreases following a reduction of commuting due to the covid-19 lockdown.
4. The incidence of crime in private residences will increase as the amount of air pollution decreases following a reduction of vehicular traffic due to the covid-19 lockdown.

attributes.title: Helping or Harming? The Effect of Trigger Warnings on Individuals with Trauma Histories
attributes.description: Trigger warnings alert trauma survivors about potentially disturbing forthcoming content. However, empirical studies on trigger warnings suggest that they are functionally inert or cause small adverse side effects. We conducted a preregistered replication and extension of a previous experiment. Trauma survivors (n = 451) were randomly assigned to either receive or not receive trigger warnings prior to reading passages from world literature. We found no evidence that trigger warnings were helpful for trauma survivors, for those who self-reported a PTSD diagnosis, or for those who qualified for probable PTSD, even when survivors' trauma matched the passages' content. We found substantial evidence that trigger warnings countertherapeutically reinforce survivors' view of their trauma as central to their identity. Regarding replication hypotheses, the evidence was either ambiguous or substantially favored the hypothesis that trigger warnings have no effect. In summary, we find that trigger warnings are not helpful for trauma survivors.
